extendedIngredients.name: flat-leaf parsley
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 oz/25 g flat-leaf parsley, coarsely chopped

extendedIngredients.name: white wine vinegar
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons cider or white wine vinegar

recipes.title: Na'ama's Fattoush from 'Jerusalem
recipes.instructions: Procedures                                                                              1                                                                            If using yogurt and milk, start at least 3 hours and up to a day in advance byplacing both in a bowl. Whisk well and leave in a cool place or in the fridgeuntil bubbles form on the surface. What you get is a kind of homemade buttermilk, but less sour.                                                                                                                            2                                                                            Tear the bread into bite-size pieces and place in a large mixing bowl. Addyour fermented yogurt mixture or commercial buttermilk, followed by the restof the ingredients, mix well, and leave for 10 minutes for all the flavors tocombine.                                                                                                                            3                                                                            Spoon the fattoush into serving bowls, drizzle with some olive oil, and garnish generously with sumac.

steps.step: If using yogurt and milk, start at least 3 hours and up to a day in advance byplacing both in a bowl.
Whisk well and leave in a cool place or in the fridgeuntil bubbles form on the surface. What you get is a kind of homemade buttermilk, but less sour.
Tear the bread into bite-size pieces and place in a large mixing bowl.
Addyour fermented yogurt mixture or commercial buttermilk, followed by the restof the ingredients, mix well, and leave for 10 minutes for all the flavors tocombine.
Spoon the fattoush into serving bowls, drizzle with some olive oil, and garnish generously with sumac.
